Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Highly Sensitive H02 Diagnostics and Oxidation Kinetics of Oxygenated Fuels at High Pressure

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1507358 (Ju)

This proposal brings an extensive suite of experimental tools to study the reaction phenomenon of basic fuels that exist in more complicated fuels. These new tools developed at Princeton University allow researchers to look at the phenomenon with sensitivity that has not previously existed, especially under high-pressure conditions common in engines. The principal investigators propose to involve graduate students in the research and outreach activities using the Princeton Energy for Community Certificate Program.

A new, highly sensitive, quantitative mid-IR FRS (Faraday Rotation Spectroscopy) combustion diagnostic method for HO2 and OH will be developed. The proposed mid-IR FRS/IR-LAS integrated photolysis flow reactor will provide transformative capabilities and enable accurate quantification of key elementary reaction rates at low and intermediate temperatures. The measured HO2/OH, and other intermediate species, flame speeds, and elementary rate constants will fill the gap of knowledge of the current understanding of combustion kinetics at low temperature and high pressure, and will play a critical role in developing a validated, high pressure and low temperature kinetic mechanisms for the following common and important base fuels: methyl formate, methanol, and dimethyl ether (DME). The obtained high pressure methanol, methyl formate, and DME kinetic mechanisms will form the base mechanisms for other larger hydrocarbon fuels, alcohols, biodiesels, and esters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WWe developed a new, highly sensitive, quantitative mid-IR FRS combustion diagnostic method for HO2 and OH;  and this new mid-IR FRS/LAS integrated photolysis flow reactor was used to measure key elementary reaction rate of HO2 and C2H5. The branching ratio of this reaction is determined for the first time at elevated pressure due to this new diagnostic capability. Specifically, The reaction rate and branching ratio of ethyl radical with hydroperoxyl, C2H5 + HO2, a key radical-radical reaction for intermediate temperature combustion chemistry, were measured  in situ for the first time in a photolysis Herriott cell by using microsecond time-resolved mid-IR Faraday rotation spectroscopy (FRS) and UV-IR direct absorption spectroscopy (DAS). The high speed in situ diagnostic technique in this work enabled the direct rate measurement of this reaction at 30 and 60 Torr, respecdtively, and reduced the experimental uncertainty considerably. C2H5 and HO2 radicals were generated by the photolysis of an oxalyl chloride, ethyl iodide, methanol, and oxygen mixture at 266 nm. The reaction rate was determined directly from the time-resolved histories of C2H5, HO2 and OH concentrations. The measured overall rate constant for this reaction is k = (4.1 ± 1.0) × 10−11 cm3 molecule−1 s−1 at 60 Torr. Hydroxyl radical (OH) production is confirmed as the major reaction channel with a branching ratio of 0.75.


Last Modified: 01/04/2020
Modified by: Yiguang Ju

The high speed in situ diagnostic technique in this work enabled the direct rate measurement of this reaction at 30 and 60 Torr, respecdtively, and reduced the experimental uncertainty considerably. C2H5 and HO2 radicals were generated by the photolysis of an oxalyl chloride, ethyl iodide, methanol, and oxygen mixture at 266 nm. The reaction rate was determined directly from the time-resolved histories of C2H5, HO2 and OH concentrations. The measured overall rate constant for this reaction is k = (4.1 ± 1.0) × 10−11 cm3 molecule−1 s−1 at 60 Torr.
